intro: Quercus brachyphylloides, commonly known as the dwarfleaf oak, is a rare and unique species native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its small, leathery leaves that are typically less than 2 inches in length. The plant produces small, clustered acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Its foliage is dense and evergreen, providing year-round habitat and shelter. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a threatened species in its native range.
